default: (a) a {@item greataxe|phb} or (b) any {@filter martial melee weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon;melee weapon}
(a) two {@item handaxe|phb|handaxes} or (b) any {@filter simple weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} and four {@item javelin|phb|javelins}

classFeature.name: Adrenaline
entries: Also at 1st level, your combat prowess increases with the ammount of damage you have sustained. You have an Adrenaline Bonus, as shown in the Adrenaline Bonus column of the Barbarian table. Choose one of the following options:
Strength and Constitution saving throws.
Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution checks.
Melee weapon damage rolls.
If you have three quarters of your maximum hit points left or less, your Adrenaline state activates and you gain the following benefits:

items: Every instance of damage you take is reduced by an ammount equal to your Adrenaline Bonus, unless it's psychic damage.
Your movement speed increases by 10 feet.
You add your Adrenaline Bonus to the option chosen above.

entries: Your Adrenaline state remains active as long as you are in combat, or while a hostile creature, harmful effect, or enemy attack is within your line of sight. This feature won't activate immediatly if you fail to spot a hostile creature, harmful effect, or enemy attack, but rather after the effect or creature's turn has taken place. This feature has no effect on you if you are at 0 hit points.
If you have one quarter of your maximum hit points left or less, all your Adrenaline benefits are doubled.
At 7th level, while under the effects of your Adrenaline state, you can't be put to sleep or knocked unconscious, and you have advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened.

At 19th level, your Adrenaline state activates when you have less than your maximum hit points instead of three quarters, and its benefits are doubled if you have half of your maximum hit points left or less instead of one quarter.

classFeature.name: Adrenaline improvement
entries: At 7th level, while under the effects of your Adrenaline state, you can't be put to sleep or knocked unconscious, and you have advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened.

classFeature.name: Adrenaline improvement
entries: At 19th level, your Adrenaline state activates when you have less than your maximum hit points instead of three quarters, and its benefits are doubled if you have half of your maximum hit points left or less instead of one quarter.

classFeature.name: Temperamental
entries: Starting at 1st level, your emotions are stronger than anyone else, often causing you to act irrationally and violent. When a situation challenges your personality, flaws, ideals, or bonds, you must make a DC 15 Charisma saving throw to retain your composure. You have a penalty to the roll equal to your Adrenaline bonus. You can choose to fail this saving throw.

classFeature.name: Frantic
entries: Anger, sadness, fear, joy. Your emotions are highly volatile and can easily overwhelm your mind entirely. At 2nd level, choose one of the following benefits:

entries.entries: You have advantage on melee weapon attacks against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet from it and isn't incapacitated.
Your Adrenaline movement speed bonus is tripled and you add your Adrenaline bonus to your AC.

entries: While under the effects of your Adrenaline state, you can use your bonus action to enter a Frantic state for 1 minute. Your Frantic state ends early if your Adrenaline state ends. For the duration, you receive the benefit chosen above, but you can't cast or concentrate on spells. Also, you can't speak words that have more syllables than your Intelligence modifier and if your Intelligence modifier is 0 or lower then you can only make unintelligible sounds.
You can use this feature two times. You regain all expended uses after you finish a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Primitive Scream
entries: Also at 2nd level, when you enter your Frantic state, you can choose to release a sonorous scream which carries an animalistic power. Each creature within 30 feet from you that can hear you suffers the effect of the scream. You start by knowing one such effect: Fearsome Roar. Some primal paths grant you an additional one.
Some Primitive Scream effects require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Primitive Scream: Fearsome Roar
entries: When this effect is activated, each creature within your scream's area must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. A creature {@condition frightened} this way can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

classFeature.name: Primal Path
entries: At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the bond with your primal side, all detailed at the end of the class description. Your path grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 9th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Primal Path feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Primal Path.

classFeature.name: Primal Path feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Primal Path.

classFeature.name: Primal Path feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Primal Path.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 6th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 20th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.
The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 15th level in this class.

classFeature.name: Relentless
entries: At 5th level, during your turn, if you are under an effect or condition that prevents you from moving, you can still move an ammount of feet up to the extra movement speed granted by your Adrenaline state. However, this doesn't end the effect or condition.

classFeature.name: Strong Scent
entries: At 7th level, your glands produce a strong body smell akin to that of an odorous beast. This odor can be smelled up to 10 feet from you, which most creatures will perceive it as unpleasant or disgusting, specially for those unfamiliar with it.

As a bonus action, you can focus to release special scretions from your glands, which get mixed with your odor emissions. When you do so, choose one of the options below. Your secretions last for 1 minute, it ends early if you are incapacitated, die, or use this feature again. A creature that can smell your odor at the start of its turn becomes targeted by your secretions. If a secretion option requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.

A creature under the effects of your secretions can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. It has disadvantage if it's still within the area of your odor. A creature that is familiar with your smell (like one that has been exposed to it for weeks) has advantage on the saving throw. If a creature succeeds on the saving throw, it becomes immune to your secretions for the next 24 hours.

If you're thoroughly washed for 1 hour, your emissions disappear for 24 hours. Being thoroughly washed means going through a process that involves having every inch of your body scrubbed with soap and brushed (as many times as needed), having your hair degreased, then your body moisturized with oil and perfumed.

classFeature.name: Hostile Secretions
entries: Your odor changes to one of danger, like that of a predator. A creature targeted by your secretions must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute.

classFeature.name: Attracting Secretions
entries: Your odor becomes a pleasant scent which evokes nice feelings. A creature targeted by your secretions must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by you for 1 minute.

classFeature.name: Growth Spurt
entries: At 11th level, you gain the heavyweight title as your body doubles in size. Your character's weight is doubled, so you need to consume twice the amount of food and water per day to prevent suffering from exhaustion. You also gain the following benefits:

items: You double your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.
You count as one size larger for the purposes of shoving and grappling.

entries: At 18th level, your growth reaches its peak, developing stronger emissions and energy conservation. You gain the following benefits:

items: The area of your {@classFeature Strong Scent|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|7|DZC:ANA} increases to 15 feet.
The number of days you can go without eating or drinking (before suffering the effects of {@condition exhaustion}) increases by 5 after you have eaten and drunk your full required amount.
You can travel for 10 hours a day without suffering the effects of {@condition exhaustion}.

classFeature.name: Growth Spurt improvement
entries: At 18th level, your growth reaches its peak, developing stronger emissions and energy conservation. You gain the following benefits:

items: The area of your {@classFeature Strong Scent|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|7|DZC:ANA} increases to 15 feet.
The number of days you can go without eating or drinking (before suffering the effects of {@condition exhaustion}) increases by 5 after you have eaten and drunk your full required amount.
You can travel for 10 hours a day without suffering the effects of {@condition exhaustion}.

classFeature.name: Back to the Land
entries: Starting at 13th level, life in civilization has become stressful and uncomfortable for you. You gain a level of {@condition exhaustion} for every week you spend somewhere bigger than a village. In comparison, you can easily subsist in the wilderness, since you can find in one hour everything needed to feed, quench the thirst, and shelter a Large creature for a day. In addition, you are immune to the effects extreme temperatures.

classFeature.name: Savage Outburst
entries: At 17th level, when you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. When you do so, you end all conditions affecting you (except for {@condition exhaustion}) and you gain an additional turn at the end of the current one. You also have an additional action in this extra turn. Nonetheless, for the next minute you return to a savage state in which only falling {@condition unconscious} ends your Adrenaline state, you have advantage on all saving throws, and your main goal is dispatching nearby threats and running away to a safe place where you could rest.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: King of the Jungle
entries: You are on top of the food chain, standing proud at the peak from where everyone can admire your figure. At 20th level, your melee weapon attacks deal 3d6 extra damage to creatures whose challenge rating or level is equal to 15 or lower. In addition, those creatures have disadvantage against your {@classFeature Primitive Scream|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|2|DZC:ANA} and {@classFeature Strong Scent|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|7|DZC:ANA:B}.

foundrySystem.rsr5e.quickDamage.context.0: Bonus to the damage of your melee weapon attack

subclass.name: Path of the Spirit Animal
subclassFeatures: Path of the Spirit Animal|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|Spirit Animal|DZC:ANA:B|3
Aspect of the Beast|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|Spirit Animal|DZC:ANA:B|6

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Berserker
entries: Those who are governed by anger will let rage take over their minds. Those who follow the Path of the Berserker are aggressive, quick to anger, and always be in the offense, having little to no regards of self-preservation. They can be so conflictive and territorial that is hard to find them living together. All of this is compensated with their brute force, as they can easily flatten groups of small enemies.

subclassFeature.name: Primitive Scream: Eraging Roar
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your Primitive Scream to boost your aggressive tendencies. When you do so, for the duration of your Frantic state, you have advantage on melee weapon attacks made against creatures, but attack rolls made against you have advantage as well.

subclassFeature.name: Splash Zone
entries: Also at 3rd level, your swings become wide and erratic. If you have advantage on a melee weapon attack roll, you can attempt to damage another target within 5 feet of the original one and within your reach. If the lower attack roll would hit the second target, it takes damage equal to your Strength modifier + your Adrenaline bonus.

foundrySystem.rsr5e.quickDamage.context.0: Same damage type as your original attack

subclassFeature.name: Improved Strike
entries: At 6th level, when you hit a target with a melee weapon attack, for every 5 points you get with your attack roll above the target's AC you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the damage roll.

subclassFeature.name: Mindless Rage
entries: Beginning 9th level, you can't be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} while under the effects of your Adrenaline state. You also end any effect that has you {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} for the duration of that state.

subclassFeature.name: Full Swing
entries: At 14th level, your swings have enough back up strength to make up for the erratic swing. You now use the higher attack roll to determine if you hit the second target with your Splash Zone. In addition to that, if a creature you hit during your {@classFeature Splash Zone|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA|3|DZC:ANA} dies, you can target an additional creature within 5 feet of it and within your reach, following the same rules for the extra damage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Spirit Animal
entries: Strike first and deadly. This is the motto of Spirit Animals, a workforce that operates from under the eyes. Their tactic revolves around efficiency, killing their target before giving room for persecution.

These rogues can be found in many places, ranging from governamental positions as the king's private Spirit Animals, through priests who exterminate enemies of their church, to hitmans from the underworld.

subclassFeature.name: Poison Adept
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with the {@item poisoner's kit|phb} if you don't already have it. Any poison you craft using poisoner's kit has a bonus to its saving throw DC and damage equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), and it ignores resistance to poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Easy Dispatch
entries: You can get an easy kill on weakened enemies, more so if you are faster than them. At 3rd level, on your first turn of combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn yet.

In addition, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that is incapacitated, poisoned, surprised, or that can't see you, you can spend up to three d6s from your talent pool and add it to the attack's damage roll.

subclassFeature.name: Incapacitate
entries: At 9th level, you have a way to secure a kill, in case the first blow wasn't enough. On your first turn of combat, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that hasn't taken a turn yet, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition incapacitated} until the end of your next turn. The DC equals 10 or half the damage the creature takes, whichever number is higher.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: On your first turn of combat, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that hasn't taken a turn yet

subclassFeature.name: Potent Poison
entries: At 13th level, creatures have disadvantage on the first saving throw they make against a poison crafted by you.
Additionally, a creature {@condition poisoned} by you takes 3d6 poison damage at the end of each of its turns. This damage increases by 1d6 for each consecutive turn it remains poisoned.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Animalate
entries: Starting at 17th level, you become a master of instant death. If you target a creature with your {@subclassFeature Incapacitate|Barbarian Rework|DZC:ANA:B|Spirit Animal|DZC:ANA:B|9|DZC:ANA:B}, you can use this feature to make that attack more devastating. If you do, the creature is reduced to 0 hit points if it fails the saving throw against Incapacitate, and it becomes {@condition incapacitated} and vulnerable to all damage until the end of your next turn on a successful save.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again on the same creature for the next 24 hours.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: On your first turn of combat, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that hasn't taken a turn yet

action.name: Convince
entries: As an action, you attempt to manipulate a creature into thinking what you want it to think. Choose a creature within 30 feet from you that can see or hear you. Make a Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) or Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check (your choice) contested by the target's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. If you have done anything harmful to the creature within the last minute, you have disadvantage on your check. If you succeed, the creature will be swayed to your point of view to a reasonable degree. This can also cause the creature to turn friendly, indifferent, or hostile towards certain creatures, either of your or the DM's choice. Your DM has the final judgement on what the creature will do or how it will behave.

action.name: Disable
entries: As an action, you attempt to momentarily disable one of a creature's senses, be it throwing debris at its eyes, making a deafening noise next to its ears, or dishing out a dirty attack to its eyes or ears. Choose a creature within your reach that is no more than one size larger than you. You can either target its eyes or ears, if it has any. The creature must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity or Constitution saving throw (its choice) or become {@condition blinded} or {@condition deafened} until the start of your next turn, if you targeted the eyes or ears, respectively.

action.name: Distract
entries: As an action, you do everything you can to distract one creature that you can see. Until the start of your next turn, while that creature is within 5 feet from you and you aren't incapacitated, your target has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you, and disadvantage on {@skill Perception} checks.

action.name: Intimidate
entries: As an action, you attempt to intimidate a creature. Choose a creature within 30 feet from you that can see or hear you. Make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check contested by the target's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. If you succeed, the target is {@condition frightened} of you until the start of your next turn.

action.name: Steal
entries: As an action, you try to take a Small object without being noticed, which usually requires at least one free hand. The object you are trying to steal can be unsecured, worn or carried, but it can't weight more than half a pound, and it mustn't be extremely noticeable or difficult to remove (like worn clothes or armor, or wielded objects).

To steal an object you must make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hands}) check against the Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check of any observer in the area (passive Perception if they aren't in combat or alert), including the creature you are trying to steal from (if any). An observer sees you if it succeeds on the check. If the object is unsecured, you take it regardless of this result. If you fail on the check against the creature you are trying to steal from, you also fail to take the object. You also automatically fail the check against the creature you are trying to steal from if it's in combat or alert.
If the object is closely guarded (like inside a pocket or a sheathed weapon), you take a penalty to your Sleight of Hands check, usually a -5 penalty.

entries.name: Rogue
entries: The halfling signals her companions to wait, then scouts the dungeon ahead on her own, disabling a potential trap and unlocking the door at the end of the hallway with her thieves' tools. After making sure there were no sounds to be heard from the other side, she steps into the darkness to hide and signals her teammates to procede forward.

Causing an uproar in the tavern for cheating on a card game, the goblin is immediatly surrounded by a group of violent drunks. However, he is well experienced in getting out of this predicament. He pulls out a harmonica from his pants and starts playing a catchy tune that slowly but surely shifts the mood of the place, enticing everyone to join the song, wether by complimenting the music or dancing. Once everyone has forgotten about the little fella's misdeed, he flees with a purse filled with the sap's money.

The unsuspecting group eats the food provided by the nice lady. Suddenly everyone falls unconscious on their plates. The lady then takes her time to cage each one of them, realizing too late one of them is missing. It's none other than the half-elf, who was faking being affected by the poison, waiting for the second the lady wasn't looking to make her escape. Enraged, she tries to pursue her, only to fall victim to a trap that renders her motionless. As she tries to escape, the half-elf jumps in to inject her with her own poison, making her fall unconscious. She cages her and releases her friends, waiting for them to wake up to leave together.

Rogues exploit their talents to get the upper hand in any situation. They have a knack for finding the solution to just about any problem, demonstrating a resourcefulness and versatility that is the cornerstone of any successful adventuring party.

entries.name: Skill and Precision
entries: Rogues devote much more effort mastering the use of a variety of skills than perfecting their combat abilities, obtaining a broad expertise that few other characters can match. Many rogues focus on stealth and deception, while others refine the skills that help them in a dungeon environment, such as climbing, finding and disarming traps, and opening locks.

When it comes to combat, rogues prioritize cunning over brute strength. They avoid danger, placing themselves in safe positions, using their quickness to aid the party by creating openings for them to attack the enemy and ensuring fail-safes to maximize their chances to win. Although, some rogues do acquire abilities that make them capable foes, like precise and powerful attacks, or evading mortal blows.

entries.name: A Shady Living
entries: Rogues commonly originate from cities and lawless lands, usually from a necessity to survive in a hostile environment, one where you have to compete for food, watch your back at every corner, lie to live another die, and even kill for a couple copper coins. Thus, they have to learn every trick they can to survive. More often than not they form big groups and organizations to protect themselves, like thieves' guilds, crime families, or a band of outlaws.

In other cases, rogues are born from professions that require advanced skills and the will to get their hands dirty, such as spies, Spirit Animals, investigators, treasure hunters, exterminators, locksmiths, or ambassadors.

As adventurers, rogues fall on both sides of the law. Some are hardened criminals who decide to seek their fortune in treasure hoards, while others take up a life of adventure to escape from the law. Some have learned and perfected their skills with the explicit purpose of infiltrating ancient ruins and hidden crypts in search of treasure.

entries.name: Creating a Rogue
entries: As you create your rogue character, consider the character's relationship to the law. Do you have a criminal past—or present? Are you on the run from the law or an organization that swore a vendetta on you? Did you leave your previous profession due to complications with your employers or to escape a monotonous routine in search of a more fulfilling life? Are you driven by greed or some other desire?

What was the trigger that led you away from your previous life? Did a heist gone terribly wrong cause you to reevaluate your career? Maybe a successful robbery gave you the coin needed to escape the squalor of your life. Did wanderlust finally call you away from your home? Perhaps you suddenly found yourself cut off from your family or your mentor, and you had to find a new means of support. Could it be that you have an unfinished business causing you sleepless nights? Or maybe you made a new friend—another member of your adventuring party—who showed you new possibilities for earning a living and employing your particular talents.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a rogue quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score. Your next-highest should be Charisma if you plan to emphasize on social interactions or Intelligence if you want to focus on discovery and plan to adopt a magical subclass. Second, choose the charlatan background.

entries.name: Can I add this Bonus?
entries: Sometimes an ability, feature, or spell allows you to add a bonus to an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, such as the bard's Bardic Inspiration, a war cleric's  Channel Divinity: Guided Strike, the *bless* spell, the martial technique boost offensive, and many others. Other abilities allow you to reroll the die for those die rolls, such as the drunken master monk's Drunkard's Luck. There is another type of abilities, much rarer than the others, ones that allow you to add special effects to your actions, reactions, die rolls, etc., such as the monk's Evasion ki feature. These abilities have in common the lack of key words for its trigger, such as hit, succeed, miss, or fail, which is why you can choose to use these after seeing the roll, but before the DM says wether the roll succeeds or fails.

entries.name: Changes to Unarmed Strikes and the Finesse Property
entries: In this compendium unarmed strikes and the finesse property suffer important changes meant to keep balance in check.

entries.name: Finesse Property
entries: The property now allows to choose between your Strength or Dexterity modifier only for the attack roll with the weapon, but not for the damage roll. For the damage roll you still have to use your Strength modifier for melee weapon attacks or your Dexterity modifier for ranged weapon attacks.

entries.name: Unarmed Strikes
entries: Unarmed strikes are now considered to have the finesse and light properties.

entries.name: Additional Actions
entries: You can incorporate the following actions into your game: {@action Convince|DZC:ANA:B}, {@action Disable|DZC:ANA:B}, {@action Distract|DZC:ANA:B}, {@action Intimidate|DZC:ANA:B}, and {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:B}
